isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - AIR-TO-AIR CHARGE AIR COOLER - AIR LEAK TEST - LEAK TEST (AIR PRESSURE APPLICATION)

step1.para: Connect a filtered air supply to the quick disconnect fitting (Item 9) on the gauge-regulator assembly (Item 6).

Open the air valve (Item 10) slightly, and increase the air pressure SLOWLY until the gauge (Item 11) reads 30 psi (205 kPa). Close the valve and monitor the gauge with a stop watch for 15 seconds. Note any decrease in air pressure.

warning.para: To prevent possible injury from the adapters blowing off during testing, increase air pressure SLOWLY.
After testing, relieve the pressure SLOWLY through the bleed valve before removing the test equipment from the charge air cooler.

step1.para: Repeat the test at least three times to verify the results.

step2.para: THE CHARGE AIR COOLER PASSES if the pressure drop is 5 psi (34 kPa) or less in 15 seconds.

If the charge air cooler passes, the test is complete. Bleed air from the system by depressing the bleed-off valve (Item 12) on the bleed-off coupler (Item 8). Remove the air hose, gauge-regulator assembly and both couplers. Connect the charge air hoses to the turbocharger exhaust piping and the engine air intake piping. Tighten the hose clamps to the value in the TORQUE CHART
.
THE CHARGE AIR COOLER FAILS if the pressure drop is more than 5 psi (34 kPa) in 15 seconds.
Check for air leaks by using a pump spray bottle to apply a soapy solution to the hoses and the charge air cooler hose connections and test equipment. No bubbles should appear.

If the charge air cooler fails or any hoses fail, REPLACE the defective part. Assemble the charge air cooler and hoses; tighten the hose clamps to the value found in the TORQUE CHART
. Repeat the AIR LEAK TEST
.
